revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox comedian | image = Josh Thomas (8182087781).jpg | caption = Thomas in 2012 | birth_name = Joshua Michael Thomas | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|5|26|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Blackwater, Queensland|Blackwater]], [[Queensland]] | medium = Stand-up, television, radio | nationality = Australian | active = 2005–present | website = [http://joshthomas.com.au/ JoshThomas.com.au] }} '''Joshua Michael Thomas''' (born 26 May 1987) is an Australian actor, writer and comedian living in [[Melbourne]]. In 2005, he won the [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]]'s Raw Comedy Competition.<ref>{{cite web |author=Stephens, Andrew | url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/comedy-festival/did-you-hear-the-one-about-the-comedian-who-broke-even/2007/04/07/1175366526660.html | title=Did you hear the one about the comedian who broke even? |work=The Age |date=2007-04-08 | accessdate=2008-08-23}}</ref> He has since appeared on television numerous times, including as a regular and [[Generation Y]] team captain on [[Network Ten]]'s ''[[Talkin' 'Bout Your Generation]]''.<ref>[http://ten.com.au/talkin-bout-your-generation-Josh-Thomas.htm Talking Bout Your Generation – Josh Thomas]. Ten.com.au (2009-04-06). Retrieved on 2011-08-20.</ref> In 2013, Thomas created the award-winning [[ABC2]] and [[Pivot (TV channel)|Pivot]] television series ''[[Please Like Me]]'', which he also co-wrote and starred in.<ref name="abc.net.au">[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/pleaselikeme/about/] ABC2 Homepage for 'Please Like Me' TV series</ref>
==Early life== Thomas was born in [[Blackwater, Queensland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Panellist: Josh Thomas|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/qanda/txt/s3242481.htm|publisher=[[Q&A (Australian talk show)|Q&A]]|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref> He lived in [[Chapel Hill, Queensland|Chapel Hill]] and [[Westlake, Queensland|Westlake]] in Brisbane's western suburbs and attended [[Kenmore State High School]], graduating in 2004. He studied for a Bachelor of Creative Industries, majoring in Television at the [[Queensland University of Technology]], but dropped out after one year.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
==Career== In 2005 he won the [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]]'s RAW Comedy Award. He made the finals of ''[[So You Think You're Funny]]'' at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]]. The following year, he was selected to perform in The Comedy Zone, a showcase of Australia's most promising up-and-coming comedians presented by the Melbourne International Comedy Festival.<ref>{{cite web |author=Slattery, Annette |url=http://www.thegroggysquirrel.com/articles/2006/04/13/2006-melbourne-international-comedy-festival-reviews/comedy-zone/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321150652/http://www.thegroggysquirrel.com/articles/2006/04/13/2006-melbourne-international-comedy-festival-reviews/comedy-zone/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-03-21 |title=Comedy Zone |work=The Groggy Squirrel |date=2006-04-28 |accessdate=2008-08-30 }}</ref>
In 2007, Thomas' first solo show, "Please Like Me" debuted at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival, where it received the Melbourne Airport Award for Best Newcomer.<ref>{{cite web |author=Ziffer, Daniel | url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/comedy-festival/jokes-aside-kitson-is-the-best/2007/04/29/1177787966861.html| title=Jokes aside, Kitson is the best |work=The Age |date=2007-04-30 | accessdate=2008-08-23}}</ref> His live shows have toured both nationally and internationally, appearing in both Edinburgh and [[Just For Laughs|Montreal]]'s comedy festivals.<ref>{{cite web |author=Slattery, Annette |url=http://www.thegroggysquirrel.com/articles/2008/02/07/brisbane-gets-a-dose-of-festival-spirit/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724231640/http://www.thegroggysquirrel.com/articles/2008/02/07/brisbane-gets-a-dose-of-festival-spirit/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-07-24 |title=Brisbane gets a dose of Festival Spirit |work=The Groggy Squirrel |date=2008-02-07 |accessdate=2008-08-30 }}</ref> In 2010, Thomas toured his coming-out themed stand-up show "Surprise", taking it to the Adelaide Fringe, Brisbane Comedy Festival and Melbourne International Comedy Festival.<ref>[http://www.joshthomas.com.au/#/gigs Josh Thomas web page]. joshthomas.com.au</ref>
2011 saw him touring ''Everything Ever'' at the Melbourne Comedy Festival, among other locations.<ref>[http://www.comedyfestival.com.au/2011/season/shows/josh-thomas-everything-ever/ Melbourne Comedy Festival webpage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215162505/http://www.comedyfestival.com.au/2011/season/shows/josh-thomas-everything-ever/ |date=15 December 2013 }}</ref>
===Podcast=== Thomas has a podcast called ''Josh Thomas and Friend'', available from iTunes, which features Thomas and his comedian friends [[Mel Buttle]] and Tom Ward. In November 2009 a second series of the podcast was released on iTunes, and the first series was deleted. The third series was released in 2011, and the second series was deleted as well.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
===Print=== Thomas has also written articles for popular teen girls' magazine ''[[Girlfriend (magazine)|Girlfriend]]''.<ref name=token-profile>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.token.com.au/html/artists/josh/index.html |title=Josh Thomas: Comedian/Writer |work=Token Artists |date=January 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080721023753/http://token.com.au/html/artists/josh/index.html |archivedate=21 July 2008 |df= }}</ref> He had an opinion piece published in ''[[The Age]]'' newspaper in 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title= A sure-fire way Kevin can win: break a leg| url=http://www.theage.com.au/opinion/politics/a-surefire-way-kevin-can-win-break-a-leg-20100611-y3je.html | work=The Age |date=12 June 2010 | accessdate=2011-10-04}}</ref>
===Television=== Thomas has made guest appearances on the Australian television shows ''[[The Sideshow]]'', ''[[Stand Up Australia]]'', ''[[Ready Steady Cook]]'', ''[[Good News Week]]'', ''[[Rove Live]]'', ''[[Celebrity Splash]]'', ''[[The Project (Australian TV program)|The Project]]'' and ''[[Hughesy, We Have a Problem]]''.<ref name=token-profile />
In 2009, Thomas became a regular and [[Generation Y]] team captain on [[Network Ten]]'s ''[[Talkin' 'Bout Your Generation]]''.<ref name=token-profile /> He also competed in [[Celebrity MasterChef Australia]], but lost in the first heat to [[Kirk Pengilly]] of [[INXS]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/tv-radio/articles/2009/10/01/1253989983149.html|title=INXS' Kirk Pengilly wins MasterChef heat|last=AAP|date=1 October 2009|work=The Age|publisher=Fairfax|accessdate=2009-10-02}}</ref>
In March 2011, Thomas hosted the 2011 Melbourne International Comedy Festival Gala event, which is held annually in support of Oxfam.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ACR_9s1in2E ]{{dead link|date=August 2011}}</ref>
Thomas has appeared several times on the ABC discussion panel program ''[[Q&A (Australian talk show)|Q&A]]''. In a program exploring mental health issues in rural areas, he challenged Federal MP [[Bob Katter]]'s views on homosexuality and his previous declaration that there are no homosexuals in his electorate. Katter's refusal to consider the issues of gay young people in a discussion of suicide and mental health problems was received poorly by the audience and fellow panelists.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/bob-katter-struggles-for-words-on-qa-about-mental-health-problems-faced-by-gay-community-20141007-10r5n2.html|title=Bob Katter struggles for words on Q&A about mental health problems faced by gay community|date=7 October 2014|newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|author=Kembrey, M.|accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref>
==== ''Please Like Me'' ==== {{Main|Please Like Me}} In February 2013, the television series ''[[Please Like Me]]'', written by Thomas, debuted on [[ABC2]]. [[Participant Media]]'s television network [[Pivot (TV channel)|Pivot]] acquired the series for the US and premiered all six episodes as a binge marathon on 1 August 2013 to celebrate the channel's launch after premiering the first episode online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/24/josh-thomas-please-like-me-australian-tv-series_n_3645610.html|title='Please Like Me,' Australian TV Series, Explores Coming-Of-Age And Sexuality (VIDEO)|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> The initial six-part series is based on his stand-up comedy shows and stars Thomas as himself.<ref name="abc.net.au" />
In 2014, the series was nominated for an [[International Emmy Award for best comedy series|International Emmy Award for Best Comedy Series]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/awards/emmys/please-like-me-from-josh-thomas-could-get-an-international-emmy/news-story/e5ae2d2b0e309acf6fe11322a4d3db89|title=Please like Josh’s show for an Emmy|newspaper=NewsComAu|access-date=2017-02-10|language=en}}</ref> For his work on the series, Thomas has won various accolades, including an [[AACTA Awards|AACTA Award]] for Best Television Screenplay in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3436975/awards|title=Josh Thomas|website=IMDb|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref>
On 2 February 2017 Josh Thomas announced on social media that season 4 was the last, stating that "we are really happy with what we've made and feel like it is complete".<ref>http://www.facebook.com/officialjoshthomas/posts/10155094048974701</ref>
